Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
September 5, 2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date the report is approved
on CWLM and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions. In
the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please contact
the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1)An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in this
rule:

(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
agency, or equivalent agency in the country
where the person usually resides, that the
person has not been determined to be a
perpetrator of child abuse or child neglect.
The documentation shall be completed not
more than 30 days prior to the start of
employment and every 12 months thereafter.
Three of three seasoned staff files reviewed did not have annual central registry
clearances completed within 12 months of the date of the previous clearance.
Repeat Violation Established
Original Inspection Report, CAP approved 5/7/25
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to Resident Ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside
of the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The
time between the variable interval checks shall not
exceed fifteen minutes.
Observation logs reviewed did not meet the requirements of variable interval
checks completed at intervals of 15 minute or less.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff
person whose function is covered by these rules
has participated in a minimum of 50 clock hours of
planned training within the first year of
employment and a minimum of 25 clock hours of
training annually thereafter related to the
employee’s job function. At least 16 of the 50 hours
provided in the first year shall be orientation
provided prior to the assumption of duties.
Two of eleven new employees hired did not complete 16 hours of orientation prior
to assumption of job duties.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter
care institutions; initial treatment plan
(2) The initial treatment plan developed by the
social worker shall document input from the
resident, the resident's parents, direct care staff,

and the referral source, unless documented as
inappropriate.
Three of three open youth files reviewed did not include information or verification
the treatment plans were discussed with or received input from youth.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from
institutional care, all of the following information
shall be documented in the case record within 14
days after discharge:
(a) The date of and reason for discharge,
and the new location of the child.
(b) A brief summary or other documentation
of the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
(c) An assessment of the resident’s needs
that remain to be met.
(d) Any services that will be provided by the
facility after discharge.
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the
parent and with the responsible case
manager.
(f) The name and official title of the person
to whom the resident was discharged.
Three of three closed youth files reviewed did not have a discharge plan which
met the requirements of subsections (a-f).
CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance
(1) The institution shall maintain a case record for
each resident.
Three of three closed youth files and three of three open youth files reviewed
were not maintained as multiple sections were blank and/or did not include
required documents

CCI Rule 400.4167 Case record maintenance
(2) Service plans shall be signed and dated by the
social services worker and the social services
supervisor.
One of three closed youth files reviewed and two of three open youth files
reviewed did not contain completed and/or signed service plans despite the
plans being found as completed on MiSACWIS.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:.
• Orientation must be clear on training transcripts. It should be labeled as such and
there should be a checklist or list describing what tasks are included in
orientation.
• Quarterly file reviews being completed would help ensure necessary documents
are in the file and the file is being maintained in a uniform manner as required.
There are checklists at the beginning of each file section, but they're not being
utilized appropriately.
• The facility must create and follow a uniform process for employee records to
ensure all the information required by licensing rules is in the employee's file,
especially at the time of the facility's annual audit. The electronic files provided by
HR were missing multiple documents. It doesn't matter if the HR file comes from
the program directly or HR, but the file provided must include all required
documents.
• The facility should develop a process to ensure discharge plans are being
completed for discharged youth.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request or require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.

Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility had a violation for Rule 113(1)(i) on their Original Inspection Report.
The facility updated their new/transfer hire checklists to reflect the central registry
timeframe requirements, required program director sign-off prior to hire, and
required hire documents to be uploaded to the agency's internal database to
create a uniform staff file.
Financial Overview
The facility's financial budget and financial audit were reviewed and there were no
concerns noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported case management has not been run properly,
which caused many of their violations for this audit. CA reported they were not
doing what they were required to do, and the case management supervisor wasn't
providing the necessary oversight and follow-up. CA reported the case
management supervisor no longer works at the facility and they are hoping the
next supervisor will improve their processes and be more vigilant in her follow-up
and organization. CA reported one case management staff was terminated due to
all the missing items from files. CA reported the case management department
has a lack of accountability and transitions in roles have also been a consistent
barrier to compliance.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Case Manager reported she is brand new and currently in training. She reported
things were going really well and she feels very supported. She reported training is
extensive and goes over everything she would need to know, so she feels
comfortable in her role. She reported there are many positive differences from her
previous role, so she feels comfortable asking for help and seeking guidance.
Youth Specialist reported things have been going well. She reported there have
been issues with transporting the youth places in the past, but since the new
supervisors have come in, those things as well as other things have greatly
improved. She reported they are starting to teach the youth about more resources,
transportation, life skills, and independent living skills so they are more successful
upon leaving the facility. She reported she feels supported in her role with the new

supervisors in place. She reported her only concern is issues with staff scheduling
and staffing struggles causing most of the conflict.
Supervisor reported the overall culture and environment of the facility are
improving. Relationships between supervisors and staff and supervisors and youth
are also greatly improving. She reported she would like more support from upper
management. She reported they were given a list of things to improve, but not a
lot of guidance or support to implement the changes. She reported having a co-
supervisor has been very helpful. However, they need more support from
leadership and having a program director/CA split between two programs has
been difficult. She reported there is no assistant supervisor currently, so hiring for
that position will provide support to staff and youth as well. She reported they're
working on a better structure for programming and staff seem to be receptive to
feedback. She reported youth seem to be more open to providing feedback and
appear more comfortable in freely expressing their concerns.
Youth reported they feel safe at the facility and staff are nice. Youth reported the
food is good and they get enough food. One youth reported he wants help looking
for a job and staff won't agree to take him, so he has to find his own way. Another
youth reported he wanted to get a car, and he felt staff were not helping him do so.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 9/5/25 and there were no safety concerns
noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
